label: MQTT Sorting Hat
info:
Receive MQTT packets
  - listen for announce and LWT messages
  - negotiate incoming data format (CSVtoJSON)
  - negotiate packet reporting intervals
    - initially accept board defaults
    - but allow for pushing commands to update intervals
Process MQTT packets
  - CSVtoJSON
  - link out to individual flows for 
    error checking and processing
Broadcast outgoing:
  - commands
  - queries

name: sbPolling
info:
# Statusbar UI State Polling

This subflow is required to translate any event of dashborad ui_widgets into an event that can be used to trigger an upadte of a statusbar widget. Pollingis ugly but it works.

#define defFuncHMC5883 true                           // defNodeFunction bit 4 (8)

#define defFuncBMP680 false                           // defNodeFunction bit 6 (32)
#define defFuncMPU6050 false                          // defNodeFunction bit 7 (64)
#define defFuncADXL345 false                          // defNodeFunction bit 8 (128)
#define defFuncAS6500 false                           // defNodeFunction bit 9 (256)

name: Set base path
Set 404
Create http endpoint <nodered>/files/xxx  where xxx is the file name to download
For troubleshooting UDP query and responses
UDP auto discovery
info:
Listens for packets on set UDP IP 224.0.1.3 at port 8266
If payload is "mqtt-query", then we:
  set the interface name we'll query (wlan0)
  use the interface name to format command line
  issue command to CLI
  parse response
  set payload to my IP
  purge unnecessary stuff for cleanliness
  send it

name: Set commands
Azimuth
info:
Data Payload: CSV
millis = unsigned long integer
azimuth = nnn.n float
degrees per sec = nn.n float

name: AzimuthDiagostic
info:
Diagnostic Payload: CSV
magnet status (string) OR magnet strength (integer)
agc level ff
current hysteresis level 00
current offset value 00

Sample MAC 30AEA4070D64

info:
Known bug in the randomized voltage.

Sometimes causes outputs with over 
10 decimal places of output VS x.xxx

Seems to be something with Javascript's 
handling of the Math.Round function. 

DOES NOT have the same problem with the 
other randomized values. So...wtf?

$boolean(arg)
func:
// $boolean(arg)

/*
Argument type	    Result
Boolean	            unchanged
string: empty	    false
string: non-empty	true
number: 0	        false
number: non-zero	true
null	            false
array: empty	    false
array: any true	    true
array: all false	false
object: empty	    false
object: non-empty	true
function	        false
*/

const data = {
    example: [
    true,
    false,
    "",
    "Hello world",
    0,
    1,
    null,
    [],
    [ false, true ],
    [false],
    {},
    { "non": "empty" },
    function test() { return; },
    ],
};

// Casts the argument to a Boolean
const expression = [
    jsonata("$boolean(example[0])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[1])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[2])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[3])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[4])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[5])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[6])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[7])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[8])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[9])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[10])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[11])"),
    jsonata("$boolean(example[12])"),
];

msg.payload = [
    expression[0].evaluate(data),
    expression[1].evaluate(data),
    expression[2].evaluate(data),
    expression[3].evaluate(data),
    expression[4].evaluate(data),
    expression[5].evaluate(data),
    expression[6].evaluate(data),
    expression[7].evaluate(data),
    expression[8].evaluate(data),
    expression[9].evaluate(data),
    expression[10].evaluate(data),
    expression[11].evaluate(data),
    expression[12].evaluate(data),
];

return msg;

name: $not(arg)
func:
// $not(arg)

/*
Argument type	    Result
Boolean	            opposite
string: empty	    true
string: non-empty	false
number: 0	        true
number: non-zero	false
null	            true
array: empty	    true
array: any true	    false
array: all false	true
object: empty	    true
object: non-empty	false
function	        true
*/

const data = {
    example: [
    true,
    false,
    "",
    "Hello world",
    0,
    1,
    null,
    [],
    [ false, true ],
    [false],
    {},
    { "non": "empty" },
    function test() { return; },
    ],
};

// Returns Boolean NOT on the argument, the revese of $boolean()
const expression = [
    jsonata("$not(example[0])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[1])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[2])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[3])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[4])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[5])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[6])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[7])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[8])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[9])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[10])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[11])"),
    jsonata("$not(example[12])"),
];

msg.payload = [
    expression[0].evaluate(data),
    expression[1].evaluate(data),
    expression[2].evaluate(data),
    expression[3].evaluate(data),
    expression[4].evaluate(data),
    expression[5].evaluate(data),
    expression[6].evaluate(data),
    expression[7].evaluate(data),
    expression[8].evaluate(data),
    expression[9].evaluate(data),
    expression[10].evaluate(data),
    expression[11].evaluate(data),
    expression[12].evaluate(data),
];

return msg;

name: $exists(arg)
func:
// $exists(arg)

const data = {
    example: [
    true,
    false,
    "",
    "Hello world",
    0,
    1,
    null,
    [],
    [ false, true ],
    [false],
    {},
    { "non": "empty" },
    function test() { return; },
    ],
};

// Returns Boolean, true if the arg expression evaluates to a value
// or false if the expression does not match anything
const expression = [
    jsonata("$exists(example[0])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[1])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[2])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[3])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[4])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[5])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[6])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[7])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[8])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[9])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[10])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[11])"),
    jsonata("$exists(example[12])"),
];

msg.payload = [
    expression[0].evaluate(data),
    expression[1].evaluate(data),
    expression[2].evaluate(data),
    expression[3].evaluate(data),
    expression[4].evaluate(data),
    expression[5].evaluate(data),
    expression[6].evaluate(data),
    expression[7].evaluate(data),
    expression[8].evaluate(data),
    expression[9].evaluate(data),
    expression[10].evaluate(data),
    expression[11].evaluate(data),
    expression[12].evaluate(data),
];

return msg;

name: $count(arr)
$append(arr1, arr2)
$sort(arr, fun)
$reverse(arr)
$shuffle(arr)
$distinct(arr)
$zip(arr1, ...)
$now()
$millis()
$fromMillis(num, pic, tim)
$toMillis(tim, pic)
$map(arr, fun)
$filter(arr, fun)
$single(arr, fun)
$reduce(arr, fun, ini)
$keys(obj)
$lookup(obj, key)
$spread(obj)
$merge([obj])
$type(val)
$sift(obj, fun)
$each(obj, fun)
$error(mes)
$assert(con, mes)
This flow requires the npm module jsonata
info:
run 'npm i jsonata' from your .node-red directory
and set functionExternalModules to true in your settings.js file
